The minimum-bias 357 trigger efficiency is determined to be (98.8 +0.2 −0.4 )% from 358 the ratio of D + signal yields observed in zero-bias events 359 that meet, or fail, the minimum-bias requirements.
All 360 offline efficiencies are known to be reproduced accurately 361 by the simulation [13] except for the term associated with 362 the silicon detector.

We therefore use efficiencies derived 363 from simulation as inputs for the measurement and use 364 control samples of data to obtain systematic uncertainties 365 that cover potential data-simulation discrepancies in the 366 silicon-related efficiency.

Offline efficiencies ranging from 367 0.27% to 7.5% are determined from simulated events con-368 taining D + → K − π + π + decays, in which distributions 369 are weighted so that the multiplicity of prompt vertices 370 reproduces the distribution observed in data.

Control 371 samples of muons from J/ψ → µ + µ − decays and low-372 momentum pions from D * + → D 0 (→ K − π + )π + decays, 373 in which only drift-chamber information is used to select 374 and reconstruct the charged particle, are used to deter-375 mine silicon efficiencies as functions of charged-particle 376 p T and data-taking time from the fraction of charged 377 particles that also meet the silicon requirements.

The re-378 sults are compared with silicon efficiencies determined in 379 simulation, and the maximum observed deviation, 3.7%, 380 is used as the systematic uncertainty on the per-track ef-381 ficiency, resulting in an 11.5% uncertainty common to all 382 D + transverse momentum bins.
This is the largest sys-383 tematic uncertainty.

Additional systematic uncertainties 384 associated with imperfect descriptions of multitrack effi-385 ciency correlations, ionization energy loss, and hadronic 386 interactions in the inner tracker material are negligible.

body_text.text: We report on a measurement of the D + -meson production cross section as a function of transverse momentum (pT ) in proton-antiproton (pp) collisions at 1.96 TeV center-of-mass energy, using the full data set collected by the Collider Detector at Fermilab in Tevatron Run II and corresponding to 10 fb −1 of integrated luminosity.
We use D + → K − π + π + decays fully reconstructed in the central rapidity region |y| < 1 with transverse momentum down to 1.5 GeV/c, a range previously unexplored in pp collisions.
Inelastic pp-scattering events are selected online using minimally-biasing requirements followed by an optimized offline selection.

The K − π + π + mass distribution is used to identify the D + signal, and the D + transverse impact-parameter distribution is used to separate prompt production, occurring directly in the hard scattering process, from secondary production from b-hadron decays.
We obtain a prompt D + signal of 2950 candidates corresponding to a total cross section σ(D + , 1.5 < pT < 14.5 GeV/c, |y| < 1) = 71.9 ± 6.8(stat) ± 9.3(syst) µb.
While the measured cross sections are consistent with theoretical estimates in each pT bin, the shape of the observed pT spectrum is softer than the expectation from quantum chromodynamics.
The results are unique in pp collisions and can improve the shape and uncertainties of future predictions.

PACS numbers: 12.38.Qk,13.85.Ni,13.25.Ft,14.40.Lb Measurements of cross sections for the production of hadrons containing bottom or charm quarks (heavyflavors) in hadron collisions offer fundamental information to test and refine phenomenological models of the strong interaction at small momentum transfer, a regime in which perturbative expansions are challenging.

In addition, in searches for astrophysical neutrinos, knowledge of charm production cross-sections has been demonstrated [1] to improve estimates for background rates from neutrinos produced in decays of charm hadrons from cosmic-ray interactions with atmospheric nuclei.

A prominent narrow peak of approx-307 imately 3400 D + → K − π + π + decays, comprising both 308 prompt signal and secondary charm candidates, overlaps 309 a smooth background dominated by combinatorics.

In 310 311 each p T bin, we determine the yield of prompt D + decays 312 using a simultaneous maximum-likelihood fit to the un-313 binned distributions of K − π + π + mass, to separate D + 314 decays from combinatorics, and D + impact parameter, 315 to separate prompt from secondary D + decays.

The fit 316 model is a linear combination of probability density func-317 tions (pdf) for prompt D + signal, secondary D + , and 318 combinatorial background, each consisting of the product of mass and impact-parameter pdfs.

In the mass pdf, 320 prompt and secondary components are modeled jointly 321 with a Gaussian function determined from simulation; 322 the background pdf is a second-order polynomial func-323 tion derived empirically from regions with D + mass in 324 1.7-1.8 or 1.9-2.0 GeV/c 2 (sidebands).

In the impact-325 parameter pdf, the prompt (secondary) component is 326 modeled with the sum of three narrow (broad) Gaussian 327 distributions determined using simulation whereas the 328 background is modeled with a combination of Gaussian 329 shapes that empirically reproduce the impact-parameter 330 distribution of sideband events.
The only free parame-331 ters in the fit are the numbers of prompt D + (signal) 332 decays and secondary D + decays.
Tests on simplified 333 simulated experiments show that the fit estimates are un-334 biased and have proper Gaussian uncertainties.
